messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba ?
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, What are the kanji for that Masayuki?  I don t find any Shoami Masayuki listed after a cursory check, but there are Bushu Ito, Choshu and others signing
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
What are the kanji for that Masayuki? I don't find any Shoami Masayuki listed after a cursory check, but there are Bushu Ito, Choshu and others signing with various kanji that read that way.

BTW, masa is an extremely common first kanji in Ito school names. Not saying that proves anything, just a "factoid."

Jim



Out of interest, I had this message from a mate over night.

" Rich, I have this piece but without the nunome intact papered to
Masayuki-den by NTHK (Shoami). Nice wak tsuba in my case. Hope this helps. "


Rich


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba ?
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Jim and Curran, thanks guy s, I did have Bushu as well in the back of my head but the nunome kept pushing it further back for some reason :-). The tsuba is
messages.messageBody:
Hi Jim and Curran, thanks guy's, I did have Bushu as well in the back of
my head but the nunome kept pushing it further back for some reason :-).
The tsuba is not mine, I am asking for a friend. It dimmensions are 7.6
x 7.1 x 5cm

Rich

Jim Gilbert wrote:

> Curran,
> It's not unusual to find Ito pieces like this in good condition. A
> lot of these tsuba are fairly small, so the seppa dai will look
> comparatively large. Of course if Rich tells us it's 8 cm in
> diameter, then I agree that there is something strange. Based on what
> I can see in the photo it looks like a legitimate Edo period piece.
> Jim
>
>
>
> Jim & Rich,
>
> By coincedence I was reading up on the Bushu schools
> this morning as I tried to confirm a mei on a Bushu
> tsuba smith. I'm not having much luck, so may beg
> Jim's help later.
>
> I looked at your tsuba and thought Bushu Ito. I wanted
> to see if I could find similar example in some of the
> books I had out. It has some of that richness of 3-D
> carving(?) that always makes me wonder 'Umetada'.
>
> But this one looks so clean and the metal so dark &
> smooth with no gold loss, and a large seppa dai. No
> chance its modern or at least post-Edo? Very clean
> piece.
>
> Curran
>
>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba ?
messages.msgSnippet: Curran, It s not unusual to find Ito pieces like this in good condition.  A lot of these tsuba are fairly small, so the seppa dai will look comparatively
messages.messageBody:
Curran,
It's not unusual to find Ito pieces like this in good condition. A lot of these tsuba are fairly small, so the seppa dai will look comparatively large. Of course if Rich tells us it's 8 cm in diameter, then I agree that there is something strange. Based on what I can see in the photo it looks like a legitimate Edo period piece.
Jim



Jim & Rich,

By coincedence I was reading up on the Bushu schools
this morning as I tried to confirm a mei on a Bushu
tsuba smith. I'm not having much luck, so may beg
Jim's help later.

I looked at your tsuba and thought Bushu Ito. I wanted
to see if I could find similar example in some of the
books I had out. It has some of that richness of 3-D
carving(?) that always makes me wonder 'Umetada'.

But this one looks so clean and the metal so dark &
smooth with no gold loss, and a large seppa dai. No
chance its modern or at least post-Edo? Very clean
piece.

Curran


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba ?
messages.msgSnippet: Jim & Rich, By coincedence I was reading up on the Bushu schools this morning as I tried to confirm a mei on a Bushu tsuba smith. I m not having much luck, so
messages.messageBody:
Jim & Rich,

By coincedence I was reading up on the Bushu schools
this morning as I tried to confirm a mei on a Bushu
tsuba smith. I'm not having much luck, so may beg
Jim's help later.

I looked at your tsuba and thought Bushu Ito. I wanted
to see if I could find similar example in some of the
books I had out. It has some of that richness of 3-D
carving(?) that always makes me wonder 'Umetada'.

But this one looks so clean and the metal so dark &
smooth with no gold loss, and a large seppa dai. No
chance its modern or at least post-Edo? Very clean
piece.

Curran

> Jim

> the ever reliable Shoami ?
>
> Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kodogu kuestion
messages.msgSnippet: NO NO NO NO NO NO - IMHO IT WILL SCRATCH... DON T TAKE THE CHANCE... Barry Thomas. ... From: Ron Hartmann  To:
messages.messageBody:
NO NO NO NO NO NO - IMHO IT WILL SCRATCH...

DON'T TAKE THE CHANCE...

Barry Thomas.


----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann <swords@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Thursday, July 22, 2004 8:44 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kodogu kuestion


Jim, Tom -

Maybe this suggestion is a little risky, but if the writing is on a flat
surface, perhaps the careful use of a single-edged razor blade used at a low
angle to the surface (so as not to scratch or "catch") would simply "pop
off" the ink. Again, care must be taken so as not to scratch the surface
patina.

Ron
STL

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kodogu kuestion
messages.msgSnippet: I agree with Tom, in my opinion razor blades should be used only by cocaine addicts Be safe. ...

used only by cocaine addicts

Be safe.

> 34

> Jim

>   -t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kodogu kuestion
messages.msgSnippet: Ron & all, Thinking out loud, I ve used sharp-tipped picks made from wood to pop off markings in lacquer.  That works well since the lacquer is brittle (and
messages.messageBody:
Ron & all,
Thinking out loud, I've used sharp-tipped picks made from wood to pop off markings in lacquer. That works well since the lacquer is brittle (and not easy to dissolve) and there's no risk to the surface.

Jim



Jim, Tom -

Maybe this suggestion is a little risky, but if the writing is on a flat surface, perhaps the careful use of a single-edged razor blade used at a low angle to the surface (so as not to scratch or "catch") would simply "pop off" the ink. Again, care must be taken so as not to scratch the surface patina.

Ron
STL

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kodogu kuestion
messages.msgSnippet: Jim, Tom - Maybe this suggestion is a little risky, but if the writing is on a flat surface, perhaps the careful use of a single-edged razor blade used at a
messages.messageBody:
Jim, Tom -

Maybe this suggestion is a little risky, but if the writing is on a flat surface, perhaps the careful use of a single-edged razor blade used at a low angle to the surface (so as not to scratch or "catch") would simply "pop off" the ink. Again, care must be taken so as not to scratch the surface patina.

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Wednesday, July 21, 2004 5:00 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kodogu kuestion


Tom,
I haven't had to deal with that. I've found that isopropyl alcohol is "patina safe" and good for removing some of the junk that winds up on tsuba. (Although if your tsuba has a patina "enhanced" by wax it will come off.) I don't know if it'll work on sumi. There is sumi ink remover for getting stains out of fibers:

http://www.shodokai.com/shop/product_info.php?cPath=33_36_46&products_id=110&PHPSESSID=5766575043bd7ac2cb2e9b6ce3d12734

I have no idea if it would work or if it would affect the patina. My guess is that it's an enzymatic stain remover like Nature's Miracle.

Sumi should be mostly carbon with some glue binder. Since there's nothing for it to soak into here it may just come off with water and some brushing.

Jim



All-
Yes yes, I'm back thank you very much, no applause please. Here is a
kodogu question for the group. How does one remove SUMI, as in india
ink, from iron, without of course damaging the patina. Sitting here
with a tsuba in my back pocket and my enquirin' mind wants to know...
-t


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.msgSnippet: Tom, I haven t had to deal with that.  I ve found that isopropyl alcohol is patina safe and good for removing some of the junk that winds up on tsuba.
messages.messageBody:
Tom,
I haven't had to deal with that. I've found that isopropyl alcohol is "patina safe" and good for removing some of the junk that winds up on tsuba. (Although if your tsuba has a patina "enhanced" by wax it will come off.) I don't know if it'll work on sumi. There is sumi ink remover for getting stains out of fibers:

http://www.shodokai.com/shop/product_info.php?cPath=33_36_46&products_id=110&PHPSESSID=5766575043bd7ac2cb2e9b6ce3d12734

I have no idea if it would work or if it would affect the patina. My guess is that it's an enzymatic stain remover like Nature's Miracle.

Sumi should be mostly carbon with some glue binder. Since there's nothing for it to soak into here it may just come off with water and some brushing.

Jim



All-
Yes yes, I'm back thank you very much, no applause please. Here is a
kodogu question for the group. How does one remove SUMI, as in india
ink, from iron, without of course damaging the patina. Sitting here
with a tsuba in my back pocket and my enquirin' mind wants to know...
-t


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Kodogu kuestion
messages.msgSnippet: Welcome back big fella, did you buy a PC finally ? :-) Acetate would be too harsh I suspect, maybe a soft cloth and a gentle detergent  and lot s of elbow
messages.messageBody:
Welcome back big fella, did you buy a PC finally ? :-)

Acetate would be too harsh I suspect, maybe a soft cloth and a gentle
detergent and lot's of elbow grease ?.

Cheers

Rich
